org.nlpcraft.model.intent

Annotation Type NCIntent


  • @Documented
 @Retention(value=RUNTIME)
 @Target(value=METHOD)
public @interface NCIntent
    Annotation to define an intent on the method serving as its callback. This annotation takes a string value that defines an intent via text-based intent DSL. This annotation can only be used on methods in NCModel subclass that is configured as data model class in data probe configuration - no other classes will be scanned for this annotation. See also @NCIntentRef for a sister annotation that can be used for intent defined externally.

    When a model get deployed in the probe, the probe will scan model's class for this annotation. When found during the scan, each annotation will be compiled into an intent and added to the model's newly created intent solver. Note that model's existing NCModel.query(NCQueryContext) method implementation will be overridden, if any.

    The method annotated with this annotation should have the following properties:

    • It should be public instance method.
    • Method should have return type of NCQueryResult.
    • Method can have zero or more parameters:
      • Parameter of type NCIntentSolverContext, if present, should always be first.
      • Any other parameters (other than the first optional NCIntentSolverContext) should have @NCIntentTerm annotation. See @NCIntentTerm annotation for more details on its parameter type.
    • Method should generally support reflection-based invocation.

    Text-based Intent DSL

    Here's a Scala example of an intent defined using @NCIntent annotation: 
     @NCIntent("id=my_intent conv=false term(t1)={group=='grp' && ~MY_META@@'item'}? term(t2)={id=='tok2'}*")
 def onMatch(
      ctx: NCIntentSolverContext,
      @NCIntentTerm("t1") t1Tok: Option[NCToken],
      @NCIntentTerm("t2") t2Toks: List[NCToken]): NCQueryResult) {
     ...
 }
    Notes on text-based Intent DSL:
    • Intent definition starts with mandatory intent ID: id=my_intent. Intent ID can be any arbitrary string (see ANTLR4 grammar for details).
    • Optional conv=false defines whether or not the intent is conversational (true is default).
    • Optional order=true defines whether or not the intent is ordered (false is default).
    • Intent should have at least one term. For the intent to match all of its terms have to be found (i.e. matched) in the user input.
    • term(t1)={group == 'grp' && ~MY_META @@ 'item'}? denotes a term (a.k.a. a slot). Each term has an optional ID (t1), rule or rules combined using && or || logical combinators and optional quantifier (? in this case). See class NCIntentSolver.RULE and ANTLR4 grammar for details on what different rules are available.
    • Aforementioned term quantifiers can be one of the following:
      • [n,m] - means from n to m inclusive
      • ? - is equivalent to [0,1]
      • * - is equivalent to [0,2147483647]
      • + - is equivalent to [1,2147483647]
      • By default when quantifier is omitted - [1,1]
    • Note that string right-hand values in rule's binary operations should be placed in single quotes, as in: id=='tok2'.
    Here's another intent from Light Switch Scala example: 
         @NCIntent("id=act conv=false term(act)={group == 'act'} term(loc)={id == 'ls:loc'}*")
     def onMatch(
         @NCIntentTerm("act") actTok: NCToken,
         @NCIntentTerm("loc") locToks: List[NCToken]
     ): NCQueryResult = {
     ...
     }
    Here's an intent from Alarm Clock Java example: 
         @NCIntent("" +
         "id=alarm " +
         "term={id=='x:alarm'} " +
         "term(nums)={id=='nlpcraft:num' && ~NUM_UNITTYPE=='datetime' && ~NUM_ISEQUALCONDITION==true}[0,7]")
     private NCQueryResult onMatch(
         NCIntentSolverContext ctx,
         @NCIntentTerm("nums") List<NCToken> numToks
     ) {
     ...
     }
    Here's an intent from Time Java example: 
         @NCIntent("id=intent1 conv=false term={id == 'x:time'}")
     private NCQueryResult onLocalMatch(NCIntentSolverContext ctx) {
     ...
     }

    ANTLR4 Grammar

    Here's the ANTLR4 grammar for text-based intent DSL for the reference: 
     intent: intentId convDecl? orderDecl? terms EOF;
 intentId: 'id' EQ ID;
 convDecl: 'conv' EQ BOOL;
 orderDecl: 'order' EQ BOOL;
 terms: term | terms term;
 term: 'term' termId? EQ LCURLY item RCURLY minMax?;
 termId: LPAREN ID RPAREN;
 item
     : predicate
     | LPAREN item RPAREN
     | item AND item
     | item OR item
     | EXCL item
     ;
 predicate
     : 'id' PRED_OP rvalue
     | 'parent' PRED_OP rvalue
     | 'group' PRED_OP rvalue
     | 'value' PRED_OP rvalue
     | meta PRED_OP rvalue
     ;
 rvalue
     : 'null'
     | BOOL
     | DEC_NUM
     | FLOAT_NUM
     | SQUOTE ~'\''* SQUOTE
     ;
 minMax: minMaxShortcut | minMaxRange;
 minMaxShortcut: PLUS | QUESTION | STAR;
 minMaxRange: LBR INT COMMA INT RBR;
 meta
     : TILDA ID
     | TILDA ID LBR INT RBR
     | TILDA ID LBR SQUOTE ~'\''+ SQUOTE RBR
     ;
 PRED_OP: '==' | '!=' | '>=' | '<=' | '%%' | '!%' | '>' | '<' | '@@' | '!@' | '@#' | '!#' | '@$' | '!$';
 AND: '&&';
 OR: '||';
 EXCL: '!';
 LPAREN: '(';
 RPAREN: ')';
 LCURLY: '{';
 RCURLY: '}';
 SQUOTE: '\'';
 TILDA: '~';
 LBR: '[';
 RBR: ']';
 COMMA: ',';
 COLON: ':';
 MINUS: '-';
 DOT: '.';
 UNDERSCORE: '_';
 EQ: '=';
 PLUS: '+';
 QUESTION: '?';
 STAR: '*';
 BOOL: 'true' | 'false';
 INT: [0-9]+;
 DEC_NUM: MINUS? INT;
 FLOAT_NUM: MINUS? INT DOT INT;
 ID: ([a-z]|[A-Z])+ ([a-z]|[A-Z]|[0-9]|COLON|MINUS|UNDERSCORE)*;
 WS : [ \r\t\n]+ -> skip ;

 ErrorCharacter
   : .
   ;
    See Also:
    NCIntentRef, NCIntentTerm

        Intent specification using text-based Intent DSL.

        Intent specification using text-based Intent DSL.
